noun.description: A destructive wave of highly compressed air spreading outward from an explosion.
examples: they were thrown backward by the blast

noun.description: A strong gust of wind or air.
A single loud note of a horn, whistle, or other noisemaking device.
examples: a blast of the ship's siren
I braced myself for the inevitable blast

noun.description: An enjoyable experience or lively party.
examples: it could turn out to be a real blast

verb.description: Blow up or break apart (something solid) with explosives.
examples: quantities of solid rock had to be blasted away
the explosion blasted out hundreds of windows

verb.description: Make or cause to make a loud continuous musical or other noise.
examples: music blasted out at full volume
an impatient motorist blasted his horn

verb.description: Kick, strike, or throw (a ball) hard.
examples: Ripken blasted the ball into the gap in right field
the school was blasted by government inspectors

verb.description: (of a wind or other natural force) wither, shrivel, or blight (a plant)
examples: crops blasted on the eve of harvest

phrases: a request for a real old blast from the past
For those of us who were active in the antiwar movement, it's a blast from the past.
This morning, while listening to the radio on the way to work, I heard an absolutely great blast from the past!
Wow - what a blast from the past to see a list of my old co-workers.
I got an e-mail the other day from an old friend, one of those blasts from the past that take you back in time.
The rockets of the ship flared and they blasted off.
I wouldn't want to miss it when the rocket blasts off.
Above our heads an enormous spaceship blasts off into a star-filled sky.
Current polar satellite launch vehicles can blast off carrying 1,000 to 1,200-kilogram units.
His mind fills with images of sleek, silvery rockets, blasting off into space.
origin: Old English blǣst, of Germanic origin; related to blaze.
